dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so we're talking US-China relations today, and it's, uh, it's a big one. The article really dives into how, you know, the Trump administration handled things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so we're talking U S China relations today, and it's, uh, it's a big one. The article really dives into how, you know, the Trump administration handled things.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, huge. And it starts by saying Trump's whole "go-it-alone" approach was, um, fundamentally flawed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, huge. And it starts by saying Trump's whole go-it-alone approach was, um, fundamentally flawed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumps bombastic, go-it-alone approach was fundamentally flawed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. He, like, seemed to assume he could just harm China enough that they couldn't compete economically, politically, or militarily.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. He, like, seemed to assume he could just harm China enough that they couldn't compete economically, politically, or militarily.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He seems to have assumed that his policies would harm China to the point that it could not effectively compete with the US economically, politically, or militarily.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But, um, the article makes it pretty clear no American actions can actually *stop* Chinese growth. And, you know, they were also trying to diminish China while negotiating bilaterally? Really confusing signal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But, um, the article makes it pretty clear no American actions can actually stop Chinese growth. And, you know, they were also trying to diminish China while negotiating bilaterally? Really confusing signal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But no American actions can stop Chinese growth. Moreover, at the same time that his administration was trying to diminish China, it was negotiating with it bilaterally, thereby sending a very confusing signal to the Chinese and the rest of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, kind of, pushing and pulling at the same time. And ultimately, while it no doubt damaged China, it really hurt the US too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, kind of, pushing and pulling at the same time. And ultimately, while it no doubt damaged China, it really hurt the U S too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumpian policies no doubt damaged China, but they hurt the US, too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally. And it suggests, like, a much more satisfactory approach is seeking cooperation and mutual gain where possible. [interrupts] Like, through multilateral forums.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally. And it suggests, like, a much more satisfactory approach is seeking cooperation and mutual gain where possible. Like, through multilateral forums.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given Chinas desire to be a respected member of the international community, a more satisfactory US approach would involve seeking cooperation and mutual gain when possible and limiting confrontation to vital issues. ... When confrontation is necessary, it will often be preferable for the US to work through multilateral forums.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Yeah, exactly. And not just, uh, trying to curtail *their* development, but focusing on strengthening *our* own capabilities—R&D, human capital.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. And not just, uh, trying to curtail their development, but focusing on strengthening our own capabilities-R and D, human capital.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, strengthening US capabilities in research and development, investment in human capital, and boosting productivity would achieve far more satisfactory results than attempting to curtail Chinese development.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And, like, climate change, developing countries' debt, international financial stability—those are huge areas for cooperation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And, like, climate change, developing countries debt, international financial stability-those are huge areas for cooperation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Pressing issues requiring cooperation include climate change and other environmental concerns, developing countries indebtedness, and international financial stability.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. I mean, thinking back, China used to be really poor, right? Before they opened up and joined the WTO.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. I mean, thinking back, China used to be really poor, right? Before they opened up and joined the W T O.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Until the early 1980s, China was very poor, and economic growth was anemic, because the government discouraged foreign trade and sought to produce all goods domestically, mostly in state enterprises.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah. Totally. Their trade policies reversed, they allowed private enterprise, and that just, uh, kickstarted this incredible economic transformation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah. Totally. Their trade policies reversed, they allowed private enterprise, and that just, uh, kickstarted this incredible economic transformation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the country then reversed its trade policies and allowed private enterprise. Its opening to the world triggered a remarkable economic transformation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, you know, the WTO was a big part of. They lowered tariffs, abided by rulings. The US actually won a lot of cases against China *through* the WTO.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, you know, the W T O was a big part of. They lowered tariffs, abided by rulings. The U S actually won a lot of cases against China through the W T O.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Accordingly, China lowered its average tariff rate from 40% in 1992 to 15% by 2000 (and still further subsequently) and removed other trade barriers in order to conform to the WTOs rules, before joining the organization in 2001. ... China celebrated its accession, and thereafter abided by rulings against it by the WTO dispute-settlement mechanism better than many other countries did. The US took many of its trade grievances with China to the WTO, and won most of its cases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right! But then Trump came along, and, um, he just attacked China directly, bypassing the WTO entirely with, like, non-negotiable demands and tariffs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! But then Trump came along, and, um, he just attacked China directly, bypassing the W T O entirely with, like, non-negotiable demands and tariffs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After Trump took office, his administration attacked China and its trade policies without using WTO processes. In 2018, Trump launched a trade war. He made nonnegotiable demands ... and dramatically increased US tariffs on imports from China in an attempt to get his way.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And economists were saying at the time, "Hey, this trade deficit is a macroeconomic thing. Tariffs aren't gonna fix it."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And economists were saying at the time, Hey, this trade deficit is a macroeconomic thing. Tariffs aren't gonna fix it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Economists pointed out that the US trade deficit with China was a macroeconomic phenomenon and not something that could be reduced by tariffs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. It just, like, shifted imports to other countries. So, um, his trade war, it was ultimately a failure, really hurting both countries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. It just, like, shifted imports to other countries. So, um, his trade war, it was ultimately a failure, really hurting both countries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And other countries developed large bilateral trade surpluses with the US: following Trumps tariff increases, US imports from countries such as Vietnam replaced some of those from China. ... His trade war was thus ultimately a failure that harmed both China and the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So where do we go from here? The article talks about resetting relations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So where do we go from here? The article talks about resetting relations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, like, restoring the WTO's dispute settlement, maybe rescinding Trump's tariffs if China reciprocates. And using the WTO for things like IP rights.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, like, restoring the W T O's dispute settlement, maybe rescinding Trump's tariffs if China reciprocates. And using the W T O for things like I P rights.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But both countries could begin to reset relations with an agreement to restore the WTOs dispute-settlement role through US approval of new Appellate Body judges. The Biden administration could make a further goodwill gesture by offering to rescind Trumps tariffs on condition that China reciprocates. And because disputes on issues such as intellectual-property rights and e-commerce can and should be resolved multilaterally, the US should raise these at the WTO instead of making bilateral demands.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, basically, back to a more structured, multilateral approach, rather than, you know, the unilateral stuff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, basically, back to a more structured, multilateral approach, rather than, you know, the unilateral stuff.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. And hopefully that leads to, uh, a less confrontational rivalry.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. And hopefully that leads to, uh, a less confrontational rivalry.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With luck, healthy US productivity growth could then enable the Chinese-American rivalry to proceed along less confrontational lines.
